> The maker is Nobuie and the signature is of the t=
ype now called futoji-mei =E5=A4=AA=E5=AD=97=E9=8A=98 
(bold, thick).  With=
in both the hanare and futoji-mei types there is considerable variation 
in=
 the detail of the signatures.  This example is not one of the more boldly =
executed 
futoji-mei.  As Pete crypictically indicated, an oshigata of this=
 guard is published in 
Nakamura Kakudayu and Akiyama Kyusaku's 1926 Nobuie=
 Tsuba shu (#52).  There the 
signature is described as sumari-mei =E8=A9=
=B0=E3=82=8A=E9=8A=98 ("close packed"), which is one of the older 
terms no=
w included within the futoji-mei type.  This guard is described as futoji-m=
ei in 
several later books and in the NBTHK's attribution.
> 
> The hitsuan=
a had not yet been filled when the oshigata was made.  This guard was the 
=
property of the Okubo daimyo family in Odawara until it was sold in 1931, s=
o the ana were 
likely filled by the new owner.  It is unlikely that they a=
re original to the plate given that 
they are made such that the guard woul=
d be mounted with the unsigned side as the front.  
The shapes of the hitsu=
ana are unusual.   It was clearly mounted with an o-kozuka, which 
are typi=
cally 18-20 mm wide (vs. the standard size of 14-15 mm).  As Gordon mention=
ed, 
the small size of the kogai-ana suggests it was mounted with one of th=
e narrow style ko-
Mino kogai.  The opening is too small to accommodate a s=
tandard 14-15 mm wide kogai.
> 
> The early Edo period "betsujin" (differen=
t person) Nobuie work will lack the quality in the 
metal, tekkotsu, finish=
 and carving.  The plates are usually rather characterless and the 
working=
 lacks subtlety.  The late Edo period revival pieces do indeed try to emula=
te the 
finish of the originals and as Alan mentioned some do a fairly good=
 job.  In general, the 
working of the rim is a bit forced and overdone in =
these examples compared to the 
originals.  They obviously will look young,=
 but there is also a somewhat artificial quality to 
them.  The same feelin=
g comes from later copies of early Shino and Oribe ceramics.
> 
> The metal=
, tekkotsu and yakite finish should lead to an Owari origin.  Remember that=
 
Kaneie worked in Kyoto, and everything about his guards is in line with K=
yoto methods 
and aesthetics.
